name: Classic 10
tooltip: Central creator at 10; dictates final third with vision and disguise.

name: Defensive Full-Back
tooltip: Conservative side defender; wins duels, blocks crosses, keeps shape.

name: Libero
tooltip: Sweeper-playmaker behind/inside CBs; cleans up then launches distribution.
description:
Libero (IT/DE)  Sweeper-playmaker

Playstyle: Sweeps behind the line, then strides out to pass/carry into midfield.
Diff vs Sweeper (classic): Libero adds on-ball progression; classic Sweeper focuses on pure covering and safety.

name: Anchorman
tooltip: Locks the zone ahead of CBs; screens, blocks, keeps it simple.

name: Inverted Winger
tooltip: Starts wide, cuts inside onto stronger foot to shoot or slide passes.

name: Shot-Stopper Goalkeeper
tooltip: Pure reflex/line keeper; excels in 1v1s and reaction saves.

name: Inside Full-Back
tooltip: Conservative invert  narrows to shield and recycle; less progressive than an inverted WB.

name: Complete Wing-Back
tooltip: Constant up-down runner who provides width, overlaps, crosses early/often, but still defends 1v1 and back-post.

name: Wide Central Defender (overlapping CB)
tooltip: Outside CB who steps wide, carries forward, and supports overlaps while defending channels.

name: Overlapping Wing-CB
tooltip: Wide CB in a back three who carries and overlaps to create width while still defending channels.

name: Inside Winger
tooltip: More striker-like from wide; attacks far post and central lanes.

name: Mezzala
tooltip: Half-space 8; drifts wide, combines, crosses/cuts back, arrives late.
description:
Mezzala (IT)  Half-space #8
Playstyle: Drifts wide to combine, under/overlaps, and arrives for cutbacks.
Diff vs Central Playmaker / B2B: More channel-specific movement than a central playmaker, and less ball-winning/box-to-box volume than a pure B2B.

name: Advanced Forward
tooltip: Line-leading runner; exploits space behind, high shot volume.

name: Inverted Full-Back
tooltip: Tucks inside next to the DM to create a midfield box/triangle; helps circulate and counter-press while staying compact.

name: Half-Wing-Back
tooltip: Between FB and WB in a back five; moderate width + diligent defending.

name: Stopper CB
tooltip: Steps out to engage strikers; front-foot defender who attacks duels.

name: Roaming Flank
tooltip: Wide free-role; drifts inside/out, overloads zones, links play.

name: Carrilero
tooltip: Shuttler; connects wing/full-back and midfield, covers lateral space.
description:
Carrilero (ES)  Lateral connector
Playstyle: Slides laterally to link full-back/wing with midfield, ensuring compactness.
Diff vs CM (generic) / B2B: Less verticality, more lateral coverage; prioritizes connection and balance over penetration.

name: Complete Forward
tooltip: All-round 9; can run in behind, hold up, win aerials, and create.

name: Attacking Full-Back
tooltip: More overlap and delivery than a standard FB; still reliable in recovery.

name: Inverted Wing-Back
tooltip: More adventurous inverted FB; steps into midfield and progresses with passing/carries, still overlaps situationally.

name: Cover CB
tooltip: Sits off to sweep behind the line; pace/reading to cover channels and balls in behind.

name: Sweeper (classic)
tooltip: Spare man behind CBs; cleans danger and launches play with calm distribution.

name: Holding Midfielder
tooltip: Anchors in front of CBs; screens lanes, recycles possession.

name: Wide Playmaker
tooltip: Starts wide but comes inside to dictate; switches play, slips runners.

name: Roaming Playmaker
tooltip: Free 8 who dictates tempo, carries through lines, arrives to create/shoot.

name: Target Man
tooltip: Aerial focal point and outlet; pins CBs, wins duels, lays off, attacks crosses.

name: Ball-Winning Midfielder
tooltip: Hunts the ball; presses, bites into tackles, breaks play, simple pass.

name: Wide Forward
tooltip: Wide striker; runs in behind, attacks goal more than crosses.

name: Ball Carrying Midfielder
tooltip: Drives with the ball through pressure, releases at right moment.

name: Deep-Lying Forward
tooltip: Drops to link midfield, threads passes, then arrives late in the box.

name: Enganche
tooltip: Static creator at 10; demands ball to feed runners; minimal defensive work.

name: Pivot
tooltip: Central hub who holds shape, screens lanes, and recycles with press-resistant passing.

name: Defensive Winger
tooltip: Wide workhorse; tracks full-backs, presses flanks, blocks crosses, safe distribution.

name: Shuttle Playmaker
tooltip: Side-to-side connector who also dictates tempo and progression in the half-spaces.

name: Pressing Forward
tooltip: Leads the press, harasses build-up, forces mistakes, still attacks the box.

name: Trequartista
tooltip: Free creator/forward between lines; little defensive work, heavy movement to receive.
description:
Trequartista (IT)  Free #10
Playstyle: Roams between the lines to receive on the half-turn and create.
Diff vs Classic 10: Trequartista has fewer defensive asks and more roaming license; Classic 10 can be a bit more central and pattern-oriented.

name: Deep-Block Playmaker
tooltip: Playmaker in a compact block; screens first, then hits clean outlets/switches under pressure.

name: Wide Target Man
tooltip: Posts up on a flank to win diagonals and isolate full-backs; lays off/cuts back and attacks back post.

name: Late Runner 8
tooltip: Times arrivals from CM into zone 14/box for cutbacks and rebounds.

name: Nine-and-a-half
tooltip: Hybrid 9/10; alternates between dropping to create and attacking like a 9.

name: Second Striker
tooltip: Support striker near the 9; combines, slips passes, late box arrivals, shoots.
description: How it differs from Shadow Striker: Second Striker is a link-man/foil who creates and finishes; Shadow Striker is a runner who primarily attacks space beyond the 9 to finish like a late-arriving forward.

name: Segundo Volante
tooltip: Brazilian volante who breaks from DM/CM to arrive in/around the box; mixes carries and late runs.

name: Wide Pressing Midfielder
tooltip: Press engine from wide midfield; funnels play inside, covers overlaps, transitions quickly.

name: Poacher
tooltip: Box predator; lives on the shoulder, one-touch finishes, rebounds.

name: Pressing 10
tooltip: 10 who triggers central presses and counter-presses, then creates on win.

name: Abrumer
tooltip: The cleaner DM  screens zone 14, blocks lanes/shots, and tidies danger. Parks in front of the CBs, snuffs danger with blocks/clearances, keeps passes ultra-safe.
description:
Cleaner DM
Diff vs Anchorman: Even more reactive and low-risk. Presses less, blocks and cleans more. Anchorman will step out to engage and circulate simply; Abrumer sits deeper, narrows lanes, and prioritizes emergency defending over any build-up.

name: Half-Space Winger
tooltip: Occupies the channel between winger and #10; combines inside, shoots/cuts back, underlaps FBs.

name: Advanced Playmaker
tooltip: Free creator between lines; dictates final-third tempo and chance creation.

name: Fox-in-the-Box
tooltip: Pure penalty-area finisher, thrives on quick movements and cutbacks.

name: Target 10
tooltip: Aerial/physical 10; posts between lines, wins headers/duels, lays off to runners.

name: Trinco
tooltip: Conservative screen who protects zone 14, holds shape, and recycles safely.
description: Diff vs Holding Midfielder (Pivot): More conservative and position-true. The Pivot will split CBs and pass forward when available; the Trinco favors staying put, marking, screening and short passes, rarely venturing into progressive lanes.

name: Wide Advanced Playmaker
tooltip: Starts wide, comes inside to orchestrate; switches play and feeds overlaps/underlaps.

name: Lone Striker
tooltip: Single 9 who must hold play, pin CBs, link midfield, still provide goal threat.

name: Shadow Runner
tooltip: Late-arriving runner from midfield/10; times surges to finish cutbacks.

name: Mediano
tooltip: Classic destroyer DM who hunts, bites, and breaks play, then keeps it simple. Front-foot breaker who tackles, disrupts, and resets play with simple distribution.
description:
Destroyer DM
Diff vs Ball-Winning Midfielder: Less roaming and chaotic pressing. A BWM will chase into wider zones; a Mediano is straighter-line, holds central lanes, engages duels on his doorstep, and avoids being dragged away from the spine.

name: Wide Poacher
tooltip: Back-post raider from wide; minimal buildup, maximum end-product.

name: Hold-up Striker
tooltip: Back to goal; secures long balls, lays off, brings runners into play.

name: False 10
tooltip: 10 who often drops deeper into CM to overload build-up, then reappears between lines.

name: Wide Midfielder
tooltip: Traditional LM/RM; balanced defender/crosser, supports FB.

name: Regista
tooltip: Deep conductor who dictates rhythm and range from the base of midfield.
description:
Regista (IT)  Deep conductor
Playstyle: Orchestrates from deep with range and tempo control.
Diff vs Deep-Lying Playmaker: Regista is more dominant/expressive (dictates the whole orchestra); DLP can be a quieter deep passer within a more rigid structure.

name: Cross Specialist Winger
tooltip: Beats man and delivers high-quality early/late crosses frequently.

name: Defensive Forward
tooltip: Press-first striker; closes CBs/DMs, forces rushed clearances, links simple.

name: Raumdeuter
tooltip: Space interpreter; ghosts into gaps from wide to finish/cutback.
description:
Raumdeuter (DE)  Space interpreter
Playstyle: Ghosts into weak-side gaps from wide to finish/cut back.
Diff vs Wide Forward: Less ball-carrying/1v1, more off-ball timing and blind-side arrivals.

name: Wandspieler
tooltip: Wall player target who posts up, wins contact, and lays off with one-touch link play
description:
Playstyle: Posts up with back to goal and bounces quick one-touch lay-offs to runners.
Diff vs Target Man / Target 10: Less about aerial bombardment or creative freedom. Target Man attacks crosses and long diagonals; Target 10 mixes target play with #10 creativity. The Wandspieler is laser-focused on hold-and-release combos in tight zones.


A Wandspieler (German: wall player) is a forward used as a bounce-board in combinations: he receives into pressure (often with his back to goal), shields, and lays the ball off first-time to onrushing teammateslike playing a one-two off a wall. Coaches also use Wandspieler for neutral bounce players in passing drills, but in tactics it usually means a striker fulfilling this link role.
key_traits:
Holds position against center-backs, binds them, and creates space for runners. 

Clean first touch, strong shielding, quick layoff/combination play.
differences:
Target man (Zielspieler): overlaps, but target man emphasizes winning and holding long balls/aerials; the Wandspieler emphasizes quick lay-offs and wall passes in combos. 

False nine: drops away from center-backs to pull them out; the Wandspieler tends to engage center-backs and play back to advancing teammates. 

In short: think physical link striker whose job is to make the next player better by returning the ball at the right tempo and angle.
archetypes:
Luca Toni  archetype cited when the term was popularized; strong back-to-goal, bounce-passes to runners. 

Miroslav Klose  likewise cited; excellent first-touch lay-offs and combinations in the box. 

Olivier Giroud  self-describes as a focal point for one-twos and lay-offs; widely analyzed as a wall-pass pivot. 

Edin Deko  frequent lay-offs/flick-ons to connect central attacks. 

Fernando Llorente  classic target/link forward used for knock-downs and bounce play. 

Anthony Modeste  German coaching write-ups list him as a Wandspieler/Sturmtank profile. 

Saa Kalajdi  described in German press as a Wandspieler who holds and links. 

Jordan Pefok (Jordan Siebatcheu)  coach quotes highlight his value as a Wandspieler fixing balls for teammates. 

These players embody the roles core: receive under pressure, shield, and return the ball at tempo to advancing teammatesmore bounce-board than pure target finisher.

name: Pressing Wide-Forward
tooltip: Wide presser who leads traps, counters at pace.

name: Box Striker
tooltip: Muscular penalty-area scorer; attacks crosses and pinballs, finishes through bodies.

name: Puntero
tooltip: A wide/outside forward that makes diagonal, goal-thread movements, less pure touchline crossing, more drives inside.
description: Brief: Latin-American term (esp. Argentina/Uruguay) for a wing/outside forward. Historically the outside in the 2-3-5 line (puntero derecho/izquierdo). Often implies more diagonal, goal-threat movement from the flankless pure touchline crossing, more drives inside.
key_traits: Key traits: 1v1 take-ons, diagonal runs to goal, quick combo play, finishing from wide, plus classic winger skills.
differences:
Extremo clsico: stays wider to cross; puntero more frequently attacks the box on diagonals (may still cross, but carries greater striker-like intent). 

Ala/carrilero: wide midfielder/wing-back tasked with long up-and-down coverage; puntero is a forward.
archetypes:
Oreste Corbatta (Racing/ARG)  mejor puntero derecho in AFA retrospectives.

Pablo Dorado (URU, 1930 WC)  listed as puntero derecho; scored in the 1930 final.

Classic wing era exemplars often overlap: Garrincha, Jairzinho, etc., though puntero is the Rio de la Plata term for that outside-forward role.
